newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesian tobacco stocks fall, fear slower growth.
newsitem.headline: Indonesian tobacco stocks fall, fear slower growth.

text.p: Shares of cigarette maker PT Hanjaya Mandala Sampoerna and Gudang Garam have fallen this week on investor concern over a slowdown in the growth in the industry, analysts said on Wednesday.

Sampoerna was down 225 rupiah to 8,700 rupiah on a volume of 2.2 million shares on Wednesday, while Gudang Garam closed unchanged at 9,575 rupiah after touching a low of 9,375 in active trading of 1.1 million shares.
The two blue chip stocks have fallen 5.7 percent and 3.04 percent respectively since Monday.
Analysts said negative sentiment on tobacco stocks was due to concern that growth in the industry had been slowing down.
They said the proposed U.S. legal settlement with American tobacco firms had had little impact on the local market.
"I think the market has just realised that both companies are in a mature industry," Goei Liaw Hong, head of research Socgen Crosby, said.
He said taken a bearish line on cigarette stocks since last September as he believed their potential for growth was small.
However, he said the cigarette industry's growth would be around six percent this year and Sampoerna's market share had risen to 12.1 percent in 1996 from 3.5 percent in 1990.
"This is a significant growth for Sampoerna which driven by sales volume," Hong said, adding that a number of analysts had forecast continued profit growth as a result of this.
He anticipated 1997 net profit of 470 billion for Sampoerna, lower than market concensus net profit of 520 billion rupiah.
"The downside trend for Sampoerna seems to be continued as it was traded at a price earnings of 17 to 18 times," he said, adding that fair price for Sampoerna was 8,000 rupiah.
Hong said he expected 1997 net profit of Gudang Garam of 795 billion rupiah, while the market concensus was 782.2 billion rupiah.
However, he said, Gudang Garam's potential growth was small as its already controlled about 47 percent of the market in 1996.
David Jap, analyst with Vickers Ballas Tamara also said he anticipated the industry would be slow and expected a net profit of 502 billion rupiah for Sampoerna's net profit in 1997.

"So far, I have no plans to revised down my 1997's net profit target of 502 billion as I believe its sales would be better in the second-half," Jap said, adding that his expectation for 1997 was conservative.
